results.title: Fighting Climate Change, One Laundry Load at a Time
results.abstract: Experts in the study of fungi are playing a bigger role in improving laundry detergents and, by extension, leading efforts to cut energy use.

multimedia.caption: Two Novozymes employees, Sara Landvik, left, and Mikako Sasa, looking for mushrooms in Hareskoven Forest, near Copenhagen. The company studies enzymes that speed up chemical reactions or natural processes like decay.

results.title: With Disney Deal Looming, Murdoch’s Empire Is Fractured
results.abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s decision to sell most of 21st Century Fox has many wondering what the future holds for him and the two sons who seemed on the cusp of taking over his vast empire.
results.byline: By BROOKS BARNES and SYDNEY EMBER

multimedia.caption: Rupert Murdoch agreed in December to sell much of 21st Century Fox to the Walt Disney Company, leaving many wondering what the future holds for Mr. Murdoch and his two sons.
multimedia.copyright: Cameron Spencer/Getty Images

results.title: Those Seatback Screens on Planes Are Starting to Disappear
results.abstract: They may keep passengers happy, but the entertainment systems are expensive and add bulk and weight to the seats. Plus, travelers are bringing their own devices.

multimedia.caption: Lindsay Renfro and her son Will McKinney, 6, at the Atlanta airport after arriving on a flight from Minnesota. She said she would not miss the seatback screens. “There are screens everywhere else in life.”
multimedia.copyright: Melissa Golden for The New York Times

results.title: Democrats in High-Tax States Plot to Blunt Impact of New Tax Law
results.abstract: State officials are considering legal challenges, looking at other sources of revenue and considering ways to, in effect, restore deductions that the overhaul scaled back.

results.title: Tax Law Offers a Carrot to Gig Workers. But It May Have Costs.
results.abstract: A 20 percent tax deduction for setting oneself up as a business could reward severing formal employment relationships but erode benefits and security.

multimedia.caption: The tax bill signed by President Trump could let independent contractors like Uber drivers claim a 20 percent deduction on their earnings. But some labor advocates say the provision could ultimately hurt more workers than it helps.
multimedia.copyright: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

results.title: Renewal or Gentrification? London Borough Grapples With a Revamp
results.abstract: Tottenham, a diverse but deprived neighborhood, is undergoing a radical transformation. Officials insist it’s in need of renewal. Residents aren’t so sure.

results.title: Chief of Compass, U.K. Catering Giant, Is Killed in Plane Crash
results.abstract: Richard Cousins, who led the world’s largest food services company, died near Sydney, Australia, alongside four members of his family and a pilot.

results.title: How Do You Vote? 50 Million Google Images Give a Clue
results.abstract: Artificial intelligence is making it possible for Street Views to be mined for insights about the economy, politics and human behavior — just as text mining has done for years.

results.title: Maura Jacobson, Creator of Witty Crosswords, Dies at 91
results.abstract: A superstar to crossword fans, Ms. Jacobson made more than 1,400 puzzles for New York magazine, filling them with puns and sparkling thematic clues.

results.title: Teterboro Airport: Steeped in Glamour, History and Noise
results.abstract: The airport, once a source of pride for the region, has recently fallen out of favor among neighbors who call it dangerous and noisy. Its loyalists say it is an underappreciated gem.

results.abstract: The Fed will be releasing the minutes of its last meeting, when it raised interest rates, perhaps giving insight into its thinking on economic growth.

results.title: Even in Poland, Workers’ Wages Flow to North Korea

results.title: John Portman, Architect Who Made Skylines Soar, Dies at 93
results.abstract: Mr. Portman, who was also a developer, built futuristic office complexes and hotels with towering atriums, transforming cityscapes across the world.

results.title: Tesla the Car Is a Household Name. Long Ago, So Was Nikola Tesla.
results.abstract: The star of a man once renowned as the prototype of a genius inventor has faded. But his reputation is having a revival, and his creations still resonate.

multimedia.caption: The inventor Nikola Tesla around 1896. Tesla died a poor man in 1943 at age 86, but thanks to Elon Musk and his electric car company, “now he’s getting his due,” a biographer said.

results.title: Why Are Mutual Fund Fees So High? This Billionaire Knows
results.abstract: In an era of Amazonian price destruction, mutual funds are an outlier. Weak directors, complacent investors and the lure of rich profits are among the reasons.

multimedia.caption: Ronald S. Baron, the founder of Baron Funds, at his annual conference in New York last month. “If you want the lowest fee, you should not invest with us,” he said in an interview, arguing that his skills and experience justify his costs.

results.title: Christmas May Be Over, but Holiday Shopping Is Not

results.title: Kenichi Yamamoto, Father of Mazda’s Rotary Engine, Is Dead at 95
results.abstract: He led the engineering team that produced an innovative answer to the conventional piston automotive engine. He later led the company.

multimedia.caption: A 1967 Mazda Cosmo Sport, powered by a rotary engine developed by Kenichi Yamamoto and his team.
multimedia.copyright: Mazda Motor Corporation

results.title: Sharing an Office With Keebler Characters
results.abstract: A Kellogg executive says you need to be uncomfortable to grow professionally and personally.
results.byline: As told to PATRICIA R. OLSEN

multimedia.caption: Wendy Davidson, president of Kellogg Specialty Channels, says she gets inspiration from the big pictures of the company’s brands in its offices in Elmhurst, Ill.

results.title: Deaths in 2017: Among the Luminaries, Fighters With a Cause
results.abstract: Remembering Mary Tyler Moore, Chuck Berry, Jerry Lewis, Sam Shepard, Della Reese and many more, but also a remarkable roster of champions who pressed for change.

multimedia.caption: Norma McCorvey, right, with attorney Gloria Allred in California in 1989. Ms. McCorvey was the “Jane Doe” of Roe v. Wade, but eventually changed her mind about abortion rights. She died on Sept. 22.
multimedia.copyright: Bob Riha Jr./Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Norma McCorvey, right, with attorney Gloria Allred in California in 1989. Ms. McCorvey was the “Jane Doe” of Roe v. Wade, but eventually changed her mind about abortion rights. She died on Sept. 22.

results.title: Separating the Good Honey From the Bad
results.abstract: As a child, Maribel Ramirez used honey to soothe her brother’s sores. Now she tests it for quality and taste.
results.byline: As told to PATRICIA R. OLSEN

multimedia.caption: Maribel Ramirez, a quality assurance assistant at Nature Nate’s Honey in McKinney, Tex., checks a container. She tests for color, moisture and acidity, among other aspects.
multimedia.copyright: Allison V. Smith for The New York Times

results.title: Unfiltered Fervor: The Rush to Get Off the Water Grid
results.abstract: Driven by misgivings about how tap water is treated, start-ups are turning to springs and the air for purer sources — and drawing an elite audience.

multimedia.caption: Opal Springs Water Company in Culver, Ore., bottles “raw water” — unfiltered, untreated, unsterilized spring water — for the start-up company Live Water.
multimedia.copyright: Leah Nash for The New York Times

results.title: Goldman Sachs Sees $5 Billion Earnings Hit Ahead of New Tax Law
results.abstract: The bank estimated a $5 billion charge to fourth-quarter earnings, much of it coming from taxes on overseas assets, a regulatory filing shows.

multimedia.caption: Lloyd Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, in September. The charge the bank announced will be a one-time cost.
multimedia.copyright: Brendan McDermid/Reuters

results.title: How Carter Cleveland, of Artsy, Spends His Sundays
results.abstract: The entrepreneur sleeps in, goes to yoga, sits under a tree, steams, and always has dinner with his family on the Upper West Side, where he grew up.

multimedia.caption: Mr. Cleveland’s day of leisure includes yoga and a steam bath.

results.title: Looking at Blue-Collar Factory Jobs in the Rearview Mirror
results.abstract: The road ahead for workers in Indianapolis won’t be easy, but our reporter has reasons for hope after her ninth trip there this year.

multimedia.caption: Shannon Mulcahy driving to her job at the Rexnord bearing factory in Indianapolis in May.

results.title: San Francisco’s Skyline, Now Inescapably Transformed by Tech
results.abstract: Salesforce Tower, which at 1,070 feet is the tallest office building west of the Mississippi, will be inhabited in January, signaling tech’s triumph in the city.

multimedia.caption: The new Salesforce Tower is visible from just about everywhere around San Francisco.
multimedia.copyright: Jason Henry for The New York Times
